clinical_study.brief_title: Treatment for the Mental Health Impact of Killing in War
clinical_study.official_title: Treatment for the Mental Health Impact of Killing in War: Augmentation of Existing Evidence-Based Mental Health Interventions

collaborator.agency: VA Office of Research and Development

brief_summary.textblock:
The goal of this project is to test the feasibility, acceptability, and efficacy of a treatment module addressing the mental health and functional impact of killing in the war zone.
The investigators will enroll between 12-20 Veterans who have killed in war and have been diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) for a pilot study assessing the efficacy of the six-session treatment. Veterans will be randomized either to the treatment or to the waitlist control group.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in psychological symptoms as measured by the Symptom Checklist-90 (SCL-90-R)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Measured at baseline and study completion (week 7)
primary_outcome.description: A brief multidimensional self-report inventory that screens for nine symptoms of psychopathology and provides three global distress indicators.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in killing-related maladaptive cognitions as measured by the Killing Cognitions Scale (KCS)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured at baseline and study completion (week 7)

intervention.description: Treatment will include six, one hours sessions with a licensed clinical psychologist or an advanced postdoctoral fellow under the close supervision of a licensed psychologist.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Diagnosis of PTSD
- Veteran will need to endorse having taken another life in a war zone context
- Have received some prior evidence-based treatment for PTSD
Exclusion Criteria:
- Meet current or lifetime criteria for a psychotic disorder
- Participants in current PTSD treatment will not be excluded;however,if receiving medications they will need to be stabilized on current medications for at least one month.
- If receiving Prolonged Exposure Therapy or Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, individuals will need to wait two weeks after they have completed the treatment to enroll in the study.
